statement.tex: \text{Find the integral of the function}\\ \cos 2 x \cdot \cos 4 x \cdot \cos 6 x \,

step.context: \text{The following substitution would convert}\\ f(x) = \cos 2 x \cdot \cos 4 x \cdot \cos 6 x \text{ to the more easily}\\ \text{integrable form } \cos \theta_1 + \cos \theta_2 + \cos \theta_3 + \cos \theta_4 \\ \text{or } \sum_{i=1}^{i=n} \sin \theta_i
step.reason:
f(x) = \dfrac{1}{4} [ \cos 12 x + \cos 8 x + 1 + \cos 4 x ] \\
\therefore \int \cos 2 x \cdot \cos 4 x \cdot \cos 6 x \, dx \\ \qquad \quad = \int \dfrac{1}{4} [ \cos 12 x + \cos 8 x + 1 + \cos 4 x ] dx

step.context: \text{Is the following evaluation of the integral}\\ I = \int \dfrac{1}{4} [ \cos 12 x + \cos 8 x + 1 + \cos 4 x ] dx \text{ correct}?
step.tex:

&= \dfrac{\sin 12 x}{48} + \dfrac{\sin 4x}{32} + \dfrac{ x}{4} + \dfrac{\sin 8 x}{16}+ C \end{align}
